CatDescriptText: Ollie Burriell, housewife, 615 Lincoln Street and Edward Dean, record librarian, Homewood, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, December 24, 1960, pg. A1 with question "Do you think that President-elect Kennedy was sincere in offering Congressman William Dawson, of Chicago, the cabinet position of Postmaster-General?"  Mrs. Burriell's answer reads: "I really don't know whether or not it was sincerity, but I was surprised that Dawson did not accept the job."  Mr. Dean's answer reads: "Yes, I do.  At the present time, President-elect Kennedy, in selecting his cabinet, has shown every indication that he means to serve the public by picking the right men."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Ollie Burriell wearing light colored coat and hat, standing in front of stores on Wood Street, Downtown; Portrait of Edward Dean wearing light colored coat with toggles and hat, standing in front of store on Wood Street, Downtown
